headline.main: Future Doctors, Crossing Borders; Lessons in East Harlem's Culture, Diet and Health

docs.abstract: Students at Mount Sinai School of Medicine tour East Harlem, whose residents, mostly poor and Hispanic, have health problems at far higher rates than people living elsewhere in New York; visit shops selling herbal cures from underdeveloped countries and observe numerous fast food shops and bodegas selling milk and other dietary staples at prices often higher than in wealthier areas; are asked to think about why so many health problems exist in area that is served by several fine hospitals and many good clinics; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Mount Sinai School of Medicine, at 100th Street and Fifth Avenue, sits on the green line. Step left when you head out the door and you are on your way down Museum Mile, past some of the ritziest addresses in New York City. It is the Manhattan of Manolo Blahniks and millionaire extravagance.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Shedding Pounds With Medicare'' (On the Contrary, July 25), Daniel Akst proposed that Medicare pay for prescription drugs to treat the obesity epidemic when effective drugs are developed by Big Pharma. That would be tremendously expensive, possibly unaffordable.
